questions.question: What is the location of the household?

tooltip.text: This question contains a list of possible household locations, starting with government area or district, down to the village.
List of household positions

questions.question: Second household member: given first name
Second household member: given family name

tooltip.text: Definition of head of household: a person who is identified as the main authority figure in the household. This should be the first person that comes to mind.

questions.question: How many males (0-5 years) live permanently in this house

tooltip.text: Count all people (in this age range) who reside in this household for at least 6 days a week (including the respondent) and share the same cooking pot and use the same toilet facilities.

questions.question: How many females (0-5 years) live permanently in this house

tooltip.text: Probe for additional members: those who are not currently at home, including anyone who may not be family (such as servants, friends) but who usually reside in the household.

questions.question: How many males (6-18 years) live permanently in this house
How many females (6-18 years) live permanently in this house
How many males (19-59 years) live permanently in this house
How many females (19-59 years) live permanently in this house
How many males (60 years and above) live permanently in this house
How many females (60 years and above) live permanently in this house
Total number of males who live permanently in this house
Total number of females who live permanently in this house
Does anyone in this household have difficulty seeing, walking, communicating, or have difficulty (with self-care such as) washing all over or dressing?
Does your family own the house that you live in?

tooltip.text: Residential status

INTERVIEW: is the household in any of the following at-risk household categories? Household may be in more than one category At-risk household: defined as a household at risk of not achieving or not sustaining the required sanitation and hygiene outcomes, or at risk from the public health hazards associated with unsafely managed sanitation and hygiene services At-risk categories: the county public health office should determine the at-risk categories to be flagged in this county. The following list includes a number of potential at-risk categories, but should be edited to match the priority at-risk categories identified by the county public health office

options.name: AT RISK: Disabled household member (mentally or physically)
AT RISK: Orphans and vulnerable children
AT RISK: Female-headed household (single mothers, divorcees, widows)
AT RISK: HIV/AIDS affected (or other serious illness)
AT RISK: Shared use of someone else's toilet/public toilet (don't have a toilet)
AT RISK: In-migrants (new households in last 12 months)
AT RISK: New adult households (newly formed household)
AT RISK: households with previously collapsed or flooded toilets

questions.question: Address or any unique household characteristics

tooltip.text:
Urban : Enter house number and street name
Rural : Enter any characteristic which helps distinguish this household from other similar households in the community
OBSERVE: Is a toilet facility visible in the house or household compound?

questions.question: PHOTO 01: view of outside front of toilet (door + walls + roof)
PHOTO 02: view of outside back of toilet (walls + roof)
PHOTO 03: view of inside toilet (floor + pan/drophole + inside walls)
PHOTO 04: if visible, view of surface of containment system (pit or tank cover slab)

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is the toilet facility functional? Functional toilet: the household toilet is functioning as intended and can be used (that is, it is not blocked, abandoned, or collapsed)

OBSERVE: does the toilet superstructure meet local criteria for privacy? OBSERVE: are animals prevented from entering the toilet? Privacy: toilet superstructure has walls and a door that allow use of the toilet without observation by people outside the toilet (NOTE: variations in privacy criteria may be agreed by County Public Health Office to reflect local practices). Privacy from animals: the toilet superstructure should also prevent animals from entering the toilet, to limit contact between animals and human excreta.

questions.question: Outcome result - Functional toilet with privacy

fn.fnString:
function() { return (#1699422286091.includes("G1") && #1699423357200.includes("G1") && #1699423571454.includes("G1"))
? "G1 Functional toilet with privacy" : "G0 Toilet non-functional or not private"}

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: type of toilet interface Toilet interface: part of the toilet through which the excreta pass into the containment system Examples: 1. Drophole, 2. Pour-flush pan, 3. SATO pan.

options.name: G1 VIP drophole with vent pipe
G1 Flush or pour-flush pan with water seal
G1 Dry toilet with urine-diverting drophole

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: type of excreta containment or collection system Containment system: pit or tank (or other) that contains and stores excreta Collection system: connection through which excreta and wastewater are collected Examples: 1. Latrine pit; 2. Septic tank; 3. Sewer connection. Flush to don't know: household does not know where the toilet flushes to, but no surface outlets or open discharges are visible (in this case, likely to be a buried pit or tank)

options.name: G0 Open pit (uncovered or large openings)
G0 No pit or tank (discharge to open: field, open drain, water body, elsewhere)

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is the toilet flyproof? Flyproof: toilet design prevents flies from reaching the excreta in the pit (or other containment system) VIP vent pipe with insect screen: vent pipes should be covered with insect screen to prevent insect entry into the pit or tank. Examples: 1. Pour-flush pit latrine with a functional water-seal pan; 2. VIP latrine with a screened vent pipe; 3. Dry pit latrine with a tight-fitting drophole cover.

options.name: G0 VIP vent pipe without insect screen
G0 Broken or empty water seal (no water)
G0 Open pipe (to pit or tank)
G1 VIP vent pipe with insect screen
G0 Inadequate or missing drophole cover

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is the toilet interface clean? Clean: interface of the toilet should appear clean, with no visible faeces, urine or used cleaning materials (for example, toilet paper or other paper, leaves or other anal cleansing materials). Easily cleaned: minor traces of faeces or soiled materials are acceptable only if easily cleaned (for example, if a child forgot to flush the toilet; or if the traces are not yet dry and difficult to clean)

options.name: G0 NOT clean: heavy traces of faeces or soiled cleaning materials
G0 NOT clean: some faeces and soiled cleaning materials
G1 Clean: minor traces of faeces or soiled materials (easily cleaned)
G1 Clean: no visible faeces or soiled cleansing materials

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is the toilet floor clean? Clean: floor of the toilet should appear clean, with no visible faeces, urine or used cleaning materials (for example, toilet paper or other paper, leaves or other anal cleansing materials). Easily cleaned: minor traces of faeces or soiled materials are acceptable only if easily cleaned (for example, if the traces are not yet dry and difficult to clean)

options.name: G0 NOT clean: heavy traces of faeces or soiled cleaning materials
G0 NOT clean: some faeces and soiled cleaning materials
G1 Clean: minor traces of faeces or soiled materials (easily cleaned)
G1 Clean: no visible faeces or soiled cleansing materials

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: are the toilet walls clean? Clean: walls of the toilet should appear clean, with no visible faeces, urine or used cleaning materials (for example, toilet paper or other paper, leaves or other anal cleansing materials). Easily cleaned: minor traces of faeces or soiled materials are acceptable only if easily cleaned (for example, if the traces are not yet dry and difficult to clean)

options.name: G0 NOT clean: heavy traces of faeces
G1 Clean: minor traces of faeces (easily cleaned)

fn.fnString: function() { return (#1699425852809.includes("G1") && #1699425943159.includes("G1") && #1699426059842.includes("G1")) ? "G1 Clean toilet" : "G0 Toilet NOT clean"}

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is the toilet slab made from durable materials? Durable toilet slab: the range of materials considered durable will depend on local contexts. The County Public Health Office should approve the use of resilient local materials that will not degrade rapidly under local conditions, and which provide similar lifespans, functionality and cleanliness to toilet slabs made from durable materials. Examples: 1. Concrete toilet slab; 2. Concrete toilet slab covered with ceramic tiles; 3. Structural plastic slab.

options.name: G0 No slab (open pit, faeces not contained)
G0 Partial slab (openings, faeces not fully contained)

questions.question: Durable toilet containment or collection system

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is the toilet containment or collection system durable? OBSERVE: are there any signs of collapse or damage to the toilet containment or collection system? INTERVIEW (where containment not visible): were any materials used to support the sides of the containment system? INTERVIEW (where containment not visible): does the soil collapse without support? INTERVIEW (where containment not visible): has the toilet pit collapsed in the last 12 months? Durable toilet containment (in stable soils): unlined pits may be assessed as durable in areas where other unlined pits are known to be stable and long-lasting. Durable toilet containment (in UNSTABLE soils): the pit or tank should either be lined with durable materials, or lined with resilient local materials that will not degrade rapidly under local conditions, and which provide similar lifespans and support to linings made from durable materials.

options.name: G0 No containment (discharge to open, open container)
G1 Containment lined with inadequate local materials
G2 Containment lined with blocks or bricks
G2 Containment lined with other durable materials
G1 Unlined pit (unstable soil, but not collapsed)
G2 Containment lined with resilient local materials

fn.fnString: function() { return (#1699427405024.includes("G2") && #1699427574765.includes("G2")) ? "G2 Durable toilet" : "G0 Toilet NOT durable"}

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: any evidence of surface outflows from the containment system (for example, visible outflows or leaks; increased vegetation growth around the pit; visible deposits from previous outflows) Surface outflows from containment: EITHER continuous outflows of faecal sludge or wastewater from overflow pipes, holes or leaks; OR evidence of previous surface outflows (for example, increased vegetation growth around the containment system, or visible sludge deposits from overflows or leaks). Examples of surface outflows: 1. Septic tank with overflow pipe to the surface (open space, open drain, water body); 2. Latrine pit with signs of wastewater or sludge overflow or leakage.

options.name: G0 No toilet, or no containment or collection system
G1 Evidence of previous surface outflows
G2 Single pit: not yet full (no surface outflows)
G2 Septic tank with soakpit (no surface outflows)

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: are surface outflows from the containment system ever visible? INTERVIEW: how often are surface outflows from the containment system visible?

options.name: G0 No toilet, or no containment or collection system

questions.question: COMMUNITY LEVEL ASSESSMENT: Low risk of groundwater contamination

options.name: G0 High risk of groundwater contamination
G2 Low risk of groundwater contamination

questions.question: Outcome result - Toilet with safe containment

fn.fnString: function() { return (#1699427743413.includes("G2") && #1699427885744.includes("G2") && #1702282796765.includes("G2")) ? "G2 Toilet with safe containment" : "G0 Unsafe toilet containment"}

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: Do members of your household defecate in the open or use a toilet? Own toilet: a toilet owned by the household (usually located nearby the home) Other household toilet: a toilet owned by another household (often on somone else's property)

INTERVIEW: are any members of your household unable to use the toilet? INTERVIEW (for those unable to use): are they able to use the toilet with assistance? All members use toilet: household respondent confirms that everyone EITHER uses the toilet, OR is assisted to use the toilet

options.name: G0+ Some members do NOT use toilet

questions.question: Shared toilet use: number of people

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: do you share this toilet with others who are not members of your household? Shared toilet use: shared use of a toilet is acceptable, providing that no more than 10-15 people use the toilet. The County Public Health Office should agree on the maximum number of people sharing a toilet based on local practices and evidence of hygienic outcomes in shared toilets.

options.name: G0 Toilet SHARED: MORE than 10-15 users
G0 Toilet NOT-shared: MORE than 10-15 users
G1 Toilet NOT-shared: Less than 10-15 users
G1 Toilet SHARED: Less than 10-15 users

questions.question: Outcome result - Toilet use by all household members
Individual use of toilet at all times (for each household member)

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: Ask each household member individually, the last time you defecated, did you defecate in the open or use the toilet? INTERVIEW: do any members of the household require assistance to the the toilet? What sort of assistance? PROBE: do any members of the household use the toilet sometimes, and defecate in the open at other times? In this case, response option is G0 No toilet, practice OD REPEAT for other household members NOTE: If household member is not available, or too young to answer (0-4 years), ask the household respondent to confirm OD or toilet use

options.name: Household member #1: G0 No toilet use, practice OD
Household member #1: G1 Use other household toilet (shared)
Household member #1: G1 Use own toilet (shared)
Household member #1: G2 Use own toilet (not shared)

questions.question: Outcome result - Individual use of own household toilet

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699428535663.includes("G2")) ? "G2 All household members use own toilet at all times" : (#1699428535663.includes("G0") ? "G0 All household members defecate in the open" : "G1 Some household members do not use their own toilet") }

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: has the toilet containment (pit, tank or other) ever been emptied? INTERVIEW: has the toilet containment (pit, tank or other) ever filled up? INTERVIEW: what happened when the toilet containment (pit, tank or other) last filled up? Examples: 1. Covered the full pit and dug a new pit; 2. Emptied the full pit and re-used it; 3. Connected a second pit and disconnected the full pit. 4. Emptied faecal sludge from septic tank then continued to use.

options.name: G0 No toilet, or no containment/collection system
G0 Unsafe containment: overflow to open space, open drain, water body
G3 Never emptied, not yet full (first toilet)
G3 Never emptied, previous pit or tank replaced when full
G3 Never emptied, using second pit (first pit full)

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: the last time it was emptied, where were the contents of the toilet containment emptied to? INTERVIEW: the last time it was emptied, who emptied the toilet containment? INTERVIEW (if the containment system is a lined pit or tank, which has never been emptied): what will happen when the toilet containment is full? INTERVIEW: How long were the contents stored (without any fresh excreta entering the toilet containment) before emptying? Intention to empty: household is planning to empty toilet containment (pit or tank) when full, or when required. Storage time: length of time that contents of containment were stored without any fresh excreta entering the containment (for example, alternating twin pit latrine where full pit is disconncted and contents are stored for 2 years before emptying) Licensed service provider: paid emptier that is approved and regulated by local authority to empty and transport toilet wastes Unlicensed service provider: paid or unpaid emptier who is NOT approved by local authority to empty and transport toilet wastes (for example, family members, neighbours, friends, informal local emptiers) Off-site location: site for the treatment, disposal or use of toilet wastes that is away from the household/community, whose location may or may not be known to the household. Sewer connection to licensed and functional treatment site: the Public Health Office should check whether the sewer network flows to a licensed and functional treatment or disposal site. Open container: bucket or other open container used to collect excreta (usually regularly collected and emptied).

options.name: G0 No toilet, or no containment/collection system
G0 Unsafe disposal: to open space, open drain or water body (MORE than 500m from household)
G0 Unsafe treatment or disposal: emptied by UNLICENSED service provider to off-site location
G0 Unsafe treatment or disposal: sewer connection to open discharge
G1 Risk of unsafe services: never emptied (intention to empty when full)
G1 Unsafe storage: stored for less than 2 years before use of stored waste
G1 Unsafe treatment or disposal: sewer connection to UNLICENSED or NON-FUNCTIONAL treatment site
G3 Safely managed: never emptied (NO intention to empty)
G3 Safely managed: emptied to covered pit
G0 Unsafe disposal: to open pit, open space, open drain or water body (within 500m of household)
G0 Unsafe treatment or disposal: closed container removed by UNLICENSED service provider to off-site location
G3 Safely managed: stored for MORE than 2 years before use of stored waste
G3 Safely managed: emptied by LICENSED service provider to off-site location

questions.question: Outcome result - Use of safely managed sanitation services

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699428661689.includes("G3") && #1699428820338.includes("G3")) ? "G3 Use of safely managed sanitation services" : ((#1699428661689.includes("G0") && #1699428820338.includes("G0")) ? "G0 Sanitation services UNSAFELY managed" : "G1 Inadequate sanitation services") }

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: presence and location of handwashing facility INTERVIEW: where do you and other members of your household most often wash your hands? INTERVIEW: is there only one handwashing facility, or are other facilities available?

options.name: G1 Portable handwashing facility (basin, jug, jerrycan, container)
G1 More than two handwashing facilities

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is water available at the handwashing facility? OBSERVE: where an empty water container is observed at the handwashing facility, visible wet ground (or wet materials) under the handwashing facility can be accepted as proof of the recent presence of water.

options.name: G1 Water container empty (evidence of washing)

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is soap available at the handwashing facility? INTERVIEW: is soap or detergent available in your household for washing hands? Soap: solid, liquid or powder soap or detergent

options.name: G0 No soap or other cleanser available
G0 Ash, mud or sand available
G0+ Soap in house, NOT at handwashing facility
G1 Solid, liquid or powder soap available

questions.question: Outcome result - Handwashing facility with water and soap

fn.fnString: function() { return (#1699429162796.includes("G1") && #1699430427692.includes("G1") && #1699430472221.includes("G1")) ? "G1 Handwashing facility with soap and water" : "G0 Inadequate or no handwashing facility"}

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is the household using a permanent handwashing station? Permanent handwashing station: facility made from durable materials, with a piped water connection or adequate water storage, and located in a fixed place that is appropriate for handwashing at critical times Market handwashing station: manufactured handwashing station from durable materails (bought from market or market trader) Portable basin: open container that can be easily picked up and moved

options.name: G1 Jerrycan or other closed container
G1 Portable basin or other open container
G3 Piped water tap with basin
G3 Market handwashing station with adequate water storage

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: mechanism to collect water or trigger water flow Hands-free operation: the handwashing station is operated by tap, or other hands-free mechanism that minimises contact with the water collection device and the water container

options.name: G0 Hands enter the water container (during collection and use)
G1 Water collected by hand (using ladle, cup, other)
G3 Closed water storage container with tap

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: facility to collect washing water, and facility to drain and dispose of the washing water Collection of washing water: container to collect dirty washing water (for example, a basin or other container) Drainage and disposal of washing water: drainage pipe or other facility to direct the washing water to an appropriate disposal point (for example, a soakpit or drain)

options.name: G0 No collection or disposal of washing water
G1 Collection of washing water without drainage or disposal
G3 Safe collection and disposal of washing water

fn.fnString:
function(){
  return (
    #1699430580239.includes("G0") &&
    #1699430671868.includes("G0") &&
    #1699430761393.includes("G0")
  )
  ?  "G0 No or inadequate handwashing services"
  :  (
    #1699430580239.includes("G3") &&
    #1699430671868.includes("G3") &&
    #1699430761393.includes("G3"))
    ? "G3 Permanent handwashing services"
    : "G1 Non-durable handwashing services"
}

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: when do you usually wash your hands? INTERVIEW: what do you usually use to wash your hands? Critical TOILET times: washing of hands with soap and water AFTER toilet use and AFTER anal cleansing. NOTE: households should mention critical handwashing times without being prompted by the monitor

options.name: G0 Do NOT use soap and water
G1 No mention of critical TOILET times

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: when do you usually wash your hands? INTERVIEW: what do you usually use to wash your hands? Critical FOOD times: washing of hands with soap and water BEFORE food preparation or cooking; BEFORE feeding infants or young children; and BEFORE eating. NOTE: households should mention critical handwashing times without being prompted by the monitor

options.name: G0 Do NOT use soap and water
G1 No mention of critical FOOD times
G2 Before eating, food preparation and feeding children

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: when do you usually wash your hands? INTERVIEW: what do you usually use to wash your hands? Critical INFANT times: washing of hands with soap and water by caregivers AFTER cleaning an infant of excreta, AFTER handling child faeces, or AFTER washing or disposing of a used diaper NOTE: households should mention critical handwashing times without being prompted by the monitor

options.name: G0 Do NOT use soap and water
G1 No mention of critical INFANT times
G2 After cleaning or handling infant faeces, OR after washing or disposal of diapers

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: when do you usually wash your hands? INTERVIEW: what do you usually use to wash your hands? Critical ANIMAL times: washing of hands with soap and water AFTER contact with animals, animal products or animal wastes; and both BEFORE and AFTER milking (in households that milk animals) NOTE: households should mention critical handwashing times without being prompted by the monitor Animal products: including meat, milk, eggs, blood, other animal tissues (e.g. organs and offal), animal skins and other animal parts (for example, feathers bones etc) Animal wastes: animal excreta mixed with a wide variety of materials including bedding (for example, straw and other materials), washing water, spilled feed and water, animal parts, blood, skin, feathers, and other contaminated wastes and residues

options.name: G0 Do NOT use soap and water
G1 No mention of critical ANIMAL times
G2 After contact with animals, animal products or animal wastes

questions.question: Outcome result - Handwashing with soap at critical times

fn.fnString: function(){ return (#1699430839676.includes("G0") && #1699431035188.includes("G0") && #1699431983680.includes("G0") && #1699432052966.includes("G0")) ? "G0 No or inadequate handwashing services" : ((#1699430839676.includes("G2") && #1699431035188.includes("G2") && #1699431983680.includes("G2") && #1699432052966.includes("G2")) ? "G2 Handwashing with soap at ALL critical times" : "G1 Some critical handwashing times NOT mentioned") }

questions.question: No exposed human excreta in compound

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: visible human faeces in the compound, house, toilet or in any other household buildings or facilities. Open defecation in water bodies: where groups or communities may practice open defecation in nearby water bodies (for example, people living near beaches, lakes and rivers), human excreta may not be visible in and around household compounds or communal areas. In these cases, household interviews should be undertaken to assess whether people practice open defecation or use a toilet, in combination of observation of the presence of a functional toilet (to verify claims of toilet use).

options.name: G0 Child or adult excreta observed in the compound
G1 No visible OD or human excreta (child or adult) in compound

questions.question: Outcome result - No exposed human excreta

fn.fnString: function() {return (#1699432663952 ?? "").includes("G1") ? "G1 No exposed human excreta in compound" : "G0 Child or adult excreta observed in compound"}

questions.question: Safe management of child excreta in compound

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: the last time [name of youngest child] defecated, where did they defecate? INTERVIEW: how were the child faeces collected and disposed? INTERVIEW: Where was the excreta collection tool cleaned? Unsafely washed: washing of child excreta collection tool (for example, potty) in compound, or at water point, without safe disposal of the contaminated washing water Unsafely disposed: child faeces disposed to open space, field, open drain, water body Child excreta: faeces or urine of children who are too young to use a toilet

options.name: G0 Soiled potty or collection tool unsafely washed
G0 Child faeces disposed with solid waste
G1 Safely managed: Child faeces buried
G1 Safely managed: child faeces put or rinsed into toilet
G1 Safely managed: child uses toilet with assistance
G1 Safely managed: child uses toilet WITHOUT assistance

questions.question: Safe management of diapers in compound

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: no used diapers visible in the compound Safe management of washable cloths: where washable cloths are used to contain child excreta, the cloths should be cleaned and washed in a safe place (for example, so that the child excreta do not contaminate the compound or a water point) and any faeces contained in the cloth should be safely disposed (for example, put or rinsed into the toilet, or buried). Safe management of disposable diapers: where disposable diapers are used to contain child excreta, the diapers should be properly closed and EITHER disposed to a covered waste pit, OR buried, OR collected for disposal at a safely managed communal disposal site.

options.name: G0 Used diapers visible in the compound
G0 Used diapers unsafely disposed or unsafely washed
G1 Washable cloth safely emptied and safely washed
G1 Disposable diaper put into covered waste pit
G1 Disposable diaper buried in compound
G1 Disposable diaper collected for disposal at communal site

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of child excreta and diapers

fn.fnString: function() { return (#1699432130951.includes("G1") && #1699432802923.includes("G1")) ? "G1 Safely managed child excreta and diapers" : "G0 Child excreta and diapers UNSAFELY managed"}

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: cleanliness of raw food, produce and cooked food Clean food: raw food (for example, fruit and vegetables) should be washed to remove dirt or other contamination before preparing, cooking or storing

options.name: G2 Clean/washed (produce, raw and cooked food)

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: raised storage of raw food, produce and cooked food Raised food storage: food should be stored off the ground, inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact in raised storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers)

options.name: G1 Storage close to ground (risk of contact with animals)

questions.question: Outcome result - Clean and safely stored food

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: cleanliness of kitchen utensils Clean kitchen utensils: kitchen utensils (for example, pots, pans, plates, cutlery, cups, glasses and any cutting, stirring or serving utensils) are washed and clean before storage or re-use

OBSERVE: covered storage of kitchen utensils Covered kitchen utensil storage: kitchen utensils should be stored in covered storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers) inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact

OBSERVE: raised storage of kitchen utensils Raised kitchen utensil storage: kitchen utensils should be stored off the ground, inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact in raised storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers)

options.name: G1 Storage close to ground (risk of contact with animals)

questions.question: Outcome result - Clean and safely stored kitchen utensils

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: cleanliness of empty milk containers Clean milk containers: the containers used to collect and store milk should be thoroughly washed before each milking, so that they are free of dirt and other contamination

OBSERVE: covered storage of empty milk containers Covered milk container storage: empty milk containers should be stored in covered storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers) inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact

OBSERVE: raised storage of empty milk containers Raised milk container storage: empty milk containers should be stored off the ground, inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact in raised storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers)

options.name: G1 Storage close to ground (risk of contact with animals)

questions.question: Outcome result - Clean and safely stored milk containers

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: cleanliness of empty water containers Clean water containers: the containers used to collect water should be thoroughly washed before each water collection, so that they are free of dirt and other contamination

OBSERVE: quality of drinking water INTERVIEW: is the water supplied by your main source usually of acceptable quality? INTERVIEW: what do you usually do to the water to make it safe to drink? [Options: boil, add chlorine, stain through cloth, use water filter, solar disinfection, settlement, other, NOT required] Adequate quality at collection point: water is collected from protected groundwater sources (for example, covered wells, protected boreholes, or protected water points); OR is treated surface water (e.g. treated by use of chlorine dispensers) Household water treatment: water is settled, filtered, boiled, solar disinfected, or chemically treated (for example, by use of chlorine solution or tablets) by the household

options.name: G0 No treatment and low quality
G2 Adequate quality at collection point

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: safe storage of drinking water Safe drinking water storage: drinking water is stored in clean, covered containers, separate from the water used for other purposes, and away from animals

options.name: G2 Clean, covered drinking water storage

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: safe use of drinking water Safe drinking water use: drinking water is collected and used from containers with spigots and taps, or from narrow-mouthed containers, or using a clean utensil that is only used for water collection

options.name: G2 Water containers with spigots or taps
G2 Clean utensil for water use

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of drinking water

fn.fnString:
function() {
  return (
    #1699433455365.includes("G0") &&
    #1699433503692.includes("G0") &&
    #1699433564057.includes("G0") &&
    #1699433637971.includes("G0")
  )
  ? "G0 Drinking water is UNSAFELY managed"
  : ((
    #1699433455365.includes("G2") &&
    #1699433503692.includes("G2") &&
    #1699433564057.includes("G2") &&
    #1699433637971.includes("G2"))
    ? "G2 Safe management of drinking water"
    : "G1 Drinking water is NOT adequately managed"
  )
}

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: cleanliness of water points in compound Clean water points: free from debris, solid waste, human or animal faeces, and any other potential sources of contamination

OBSERVE: protection of water points in compound Protected surface water sources (pans, dams, lakes, rivers): fenced to prevent animal access Protected water supply source catchments: protected from wastes and pollutants, including human excreta and animal wastes (for example, by excluding animals and prohibiting unsafe activities, such as the use of manure or chemical fertilisers in areas around water supply sources). Protected water points: provide separate water troughs for animal watering Protected groundwater sources (springs, wells, handpumps, boreholes): protected from contamination, wastes and pollutants (for example, by the construction of a spring box, raised parapet wall and cover, wellhead protection and sealed borehole casing).

options.name: G1 Inadequate protection of water points
G0 No protection of water points

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: drainage of water points in compound Well drained water points: no standing water visible at or around the water source (provision of drainage and soakpits may be required in slow-draining soils)

options.name: G0 Standing water visible around water point

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of water sources

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: presence of unsafely managed animal wastes inside house or kitchen Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices. Safely managed animal wastes: the house and household compound should be free of animal wastes, except in areas where manure is properly stored and managed. Regular collection of animal wastes (for example, daily collection of animal faeces and other wastes) should be evident from observation of the house and household compound

options.name: G1 Small amounts of animal wastes present
G2 No animal wastes visible in house or in kitchen

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: presence of unsafely managed animal wastes in compound (outside specific areas for safe management of animal wastes) Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices. Safely managed animal wastes: the house and household compound should be free of animal wastes, except in areas where manure is properly stored and managed. Regular collection of animal wastes (for example, daily collection of animal faeces and other wastes) should be evident from observation of the house and household compound

options.name: G1 Small amounts of animal wastes present
G2 No animal wastes visible in compound

questions.question: Outcome result - No visible animal wastes in house or compound

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: storage of animal wastes in the compound Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices. Animal wastes not accessible by animals or children: any animal waste facility should prevent animal and child access to the wastes.

options.name: G0 Unsafe location of animal waste storage
G1 Inadequate location of animal waste storage
G2 Good location for animal waste storage

questions.question: Safe location of animal waste storage

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: location of animal waste storage in the compound Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices. Animal waste storage: animal wastes should be collected and stored in an appropriate facility located away from the house, and away from child play areas.

options.name: G0 Unsafe animal waste storage location
G1 Animal waste storage too close to house
G2 Animal waste storage away from house and play areas

questions.question: Safe management of animal waste storage

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: leakage or discharge of solid or liquid animal wastes into the area around the animal waste storage facility Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices.

options.name: G0 Animal waste storage is UNSAFELY managed
G2 No leaks or discharge from animal waste storage

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of animal wastes in compound

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: location of animals and animal pens Location of animal pens: facility to confine animals, which should be located away from the house and away from child play areas (in small compounds, animals should be penned as far away as possible from the house)

options.name: G1 Animals penned close to house or play areas
G2 Animals penned away from house and play areas

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: confinement of animals within pens Confinement in animal pens: facility to confine animals, which should prevent animals from entering the home or other parts of the compound. The animal pens should limit the contamination of other parts of the compound with animal wastes, and limit contact between infants and animals. Inadequate animal pens: do not adequately limit the movement of animals or animal wastes within the compound

options.name: G2 Safe confinement in animal pens

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe separation of animals from under-5 children

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: use of soakpits or drainage to manage liquid wastes and wastewater Liquid wastes: wastewater including washing water and other liquid wastes from household activities such as food preparation, washing and bathing. Wastewater from toilets should generally be kept separate from other household liquid wastes (as it presents a higher public health hazard).

options.name: G3 Adequate wastewater soakpit or drainage

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: erosion or other damage caused by stormwater flows Stormwater: surface water from rainfall or storms. Adequate stormwater drainage: drains or other services that limit or prevent erosion from stormwater flows (for example, EITHER by transporting flows away from the compound, OR by encouraging infiltration into the soil)

options.name: G3 No signs of stormwater erosion

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of liquid wastes

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: visible solid wastes in compound Solid wastes: food wastes, paper, plastic, rags, metal, glass and other solid materials discarded by the household

options.name: G3 Clean compound with no visible solid wastes

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: facility (or service) for solid waste collection, management and disposal Solid wastes: food wastes, paper, plastic, rags, metal, glass and other solid materials discarded by the household Solid waste facility or service: covered waste pits in compound, central waste disposal site, or other waste collection service

options.name: G3 Solid waste storage or disposal system

questions.question: Outcome result - Safe management of solid wastes

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: visible standing water in compound Standing water: accumulation of wastewater (or stormwater) in compound, which does NOT immediately drain away

INTERVIEW: where standing water provides larval breeding sites, are treatment or other vector control activities used to limit mosquito breeding? Larval breeding sites: mosquitoes lay eggs directly in or near water, soil and at the base of plants in places that may fill with water. Vector control activities: draining of standing water; covering of water storage containers; filling of depressions that hold water; filling of cracks in water tank and septic tank covers; cover open vents or plumbing pipes (with insect screen). Treatment activities: use of larvicides to treat bodies of water that will not be used for drinking, and which cannot be covered, emptied or removed; use of fogging or surface applications to control adult mosquitoes

options.name: G3 Treated or managed larval breeding sites

questions.question: Outcome result - Good vector control in compound

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: cleanliness of faces in all under-5 children OBSERVE: cleanliness of face of main caregiver Clean hands: no visible dirt on hands Clean face: no visible dirt on the face Clean face and hands: assessed by observation of the faces and hands of all under-5 children in the household, and the main caregiver. If one of the under-5 children of the main caregiver does not have a clean face and hands, the outcome is not achieved.

OBSERVE: cleanliness of hands in all under-5 children OBSERVE: cleanliness of hands of main caregiver Clean hands: no visible dirt on hands Clean face and hands: assessed by observation of the faces and hands of all under-5 children in the household, and the main caregiver. If one of the under-5 children of the main caregiver does not have a clean face and hands, the outcome is not achieved.

questions.question: Outcome result - Clean face and hands

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: washing place adequate for menstrual hygiene Adequate washing place: private and clean place for washing and menstrual hygiene, with water and soap available

options.name: G3 Clean and private washing place

questions.question: Safe disposal site for menstrual hygiene wastes

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: disposal site for menstrual hygiene wastes Disposal site: appropriate facility for the safe disposal of menstrual hygiene wastes (for example, covered bins)

INTERVIEW: are menstrual hygiene materials available? Menstrual hygiene materials and products: disposable and reusable sanitary pads, tampons, and resuable menstrual cups, clean piece of cotton cloth or cotton wool, that are safe and hygienic, and absorb or collect blood during menstrual periods. Available: menstrual hygiene materials are currently available on premises (in the home or household compound)

options.name: G1 Materials are NOT available or NOT appropriate
G2 Materials are not always available or appropriate

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: vaccination records or certificates Fully immunized children: all under-5 children in the household have received the relevant vaccinations

OBSERVE: Vitamin A supplement records Vitamin A supplements: all under-5 children should receive Vitamin A supplements every 6 months, and mothers should receive Vitamin A supplements within 6 weeks of delivery to pass the vitamin on to the child through breast milk. Vitamin A supplements received: confirm that all under-5 children in the household have received a Vitamin A supplement in the last 6 months

options.name: G2 Some Vitamin A supplements not received (in last 6 months)
G3 All Vitamin A supplements received in last 6 months

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW (to mothers of under 6 month old babies): how are you feeding your baby? [Options: Exclusive breastfeeding, breastfeeding and milk substitutes; milk substitutes only; other] INTERVIEW (to mothers of under 6 month old babies): Has your baby been given anything other than breast milk since it was born Exclusive breastfeeding: infants should receive only breast milk until 6 months old. No other food or water should be given to the infant during the first 6-month period, because of the risk that this food or water may be contaminated and cause illness. Exclusive breastfeeding for under 6-month children: assess by interview, supported by observation of the foods available in the house to confirm the reported diet of the under-2 children

options.name: G1 Under 6-month children regularly receive water or other food
G2 Some water and other food received on a few occasions
G3 Exclusive breastfeeding for under 6-month children
G3 No under-6 month old children

questions.question: Nutritious diet for 6-month to 2-year old children

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: what food types/groups are present in the home? INTERVIEW (to mothers of under 2 year children): which of these foods have been fed to your under-2 children in the last 7 days? Nutritious diet: all 6-month to under-2 children received foods from 5 or more food groups during the previous day Nutritious diet assessment: by household interview, supported by observation of the foods available in the house (to confirm reported diet of under-2 children) Nutritious food groups: 1. Breast milk 2. Grains, white roots, tubers and plaintains 3. Legumes and nuts 4. Dairy 5. Flesh foods (meat, fish, poultry, liver and organ meats) 6. Eggs 7. Vitamin A rich fruits and vegetables (for example, sweet potato, kale, carrot, red pepper, mango, pink grapefruit, watermelon) 8. Other fruits and vegetables.

options.name: G1 Low nutrition diet: some or all children eat from only 1-2 food groups
G2 Inadequate diet: some or all children eat from 3-4 food groups
G3 Nutritious diet for all 6 month to 2 year children
G3 No 6 month to 2-year old children

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: insecticide-treated bed nets on all beds OBSERVE: insect screen on windows, doors and other openings Malaria-safe home: EITHER all household members sleep under an insecticide-treated bed net, OR the house has insect screen on all windows, doors and other openings.

options.name: G1 No protection: no bed nets and no insect screen
G2 Inadequate protection: some beds without nets, or some openings unprotected

questions.question: Outcome result - Malaria-endemic counties: Malaria-safe homes

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: deworming treatment records Dewormed home: all children and all at-risk adults have received deworming treatment in the last 12 months

options.name: G1 No deworming: no children or adults treated
G2 Inadequate deworming: some children or adults not treated
G3 Dewormed home (all treated in last 12 months)

questions.question: Outcome result - STH-endemic counties: Dewormed homes

Outcome result - Clean and safely stored milk containers

Outcome result - Safe management of animal wastes in compound
